intro: Paepalanthus capillaceus, commonly known as the silky puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its tall, spire-like inflorescence composed of numerous small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant is notable for its fibrous, grass-like leaves and its ability to thrive in high-altitude environments. It is often found in rocky or open habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
